content: The federal government has supported educational statistics for over 150 years, with the Office of Education established in 1867. The National Institute of Education and National Center for Education Statistics were created in the 1970s, with the NIE being replaced by the Office of Educational Research and Improvement in 1985. The National Institute of Education (NIE) and National Center for Education Statistics were established in the 1970s. The NIE was replaced by the Office of Educational Research and Improvement in 1985, which was further replaced by the Institute of Education Sciences in 2002 through the Education Sciences Reform Act. The Education Sciences Reform Act (ESRA) established the Institute of Education Sciences (IES) in 2002 as an independent research institute within the Department of Education. The National Board of Educational Sciences (NBES) advises the Director on institute policies and research priorities. The ESRA established the Institute of Education Sciences (IES) in 2002 with the National Board of Educational Sciences (NBES) advising on policies and research priorities. The IES operates through three National Education Centers and was later amended to include a fourth center under P.L. 108-446. The ESRA established the Institute of Education Sciences (IES) in 2002 with the National Board of Educational Sciences advising on policies and research priorities. P.L. 108-446 added the National Center for Special Education Research (NCSER) to IES. P.L. 107-279 enacted the Educational Technical Assistance Act (ETAA) and the National Assessment of Educational Progress Authorization Act (NAEPAA). ETAA allows the Secretary of Education to provide grants for technical assistance activities. The ESRA established the Institute of Education Sciences (IES) in 2002 with the National Board of Educational Sciences advising on policies and research priorities. P.L. 107-279 enacted the Educational Technical Assistance Act (ETAA) and the National Assessment of Educational Progress Authorization Act (NAEPAA). ETAA authorizes grants for technical assistance activities and statewide data systems, while NAEPAA authorizes national and state assessments in reading and mathematics. The ESRA established the Institute of Education Sciences (IES) in 2002 with the National Board of Educational Sciences advising on policies and research priorities. Among the changes enacted through ESRA were the creation of an independent research institute and the implementation of "scientifically-based" or "scientifically-valid" standards for research. IES operates independently with more freedom from the Department of Education (ED) compared to the Office of Educational Research and Improvement (OERI). ESRA also allows for greater oversight of IES by a technical panel (NBES). ESRA established the Institute of Education Sciences (IES) as an independent research institute with more freedom from the Department of Education (ED) compared to OERI. ESRA also requires adherence to scientifically based research standards, scientifically valid research, and scientifically valid educational evaluations. The Education Sciences Reform Act (ESRA) established the Institute of Education Sciences (IES) with a focus on scientifically based research standards and valid educational evaluations. Funding for ESRA-related programs has continued through annual appropriations legislation, with the House of Representatives passing the Strengthening Education through Research Act in the 113th Congress. Funding for ESRA-related programs has continued through annual appropriations legislation. In the 113th Congress, the House of Representatives passed the Strengthening Education through Research Act, and in the 114th Congress, the Senate adopted a similar bill. Both bills aimed to reauthorize ESRA, ETAA, and NAEPAA, amending various provisions related to IES independence, research standards, technical assistance, evaluation, privacy protection, student assessment oversight, and IES accountability. The report provides a concise description of programs and authorities established by ESRA, ETAA, and NAEPAA, as well as recent legislative action. Title I of P.L. 107-279 is the Education Sciences Reform Act (ESRA), organized into six parts authorizing IES, NBES, and other provisions. Title I of P.L. 107-279, the Education Sciences Reform Act (ESRA), establishes IES as a research institute within ED to provide national leadership in education research. IES aims to provide information on education to various stakeholders. The Institute of Education Sciences (IES) aims to provide information on education to stakeholders by compiling statistics, conducting research, and evaluations. The IES Director is appointed by the President with expertise in research and statistics. Under the provisions of ESRA, the IES Director is appointed by the President with expertise in research, statistics, or evaluation in education. The Director is authorized to propose research priorities, establish review procedures, advise the Secretary, and ensure activities are objective and free of bias. ESRA also authorizes specific duties for the Director. The ESRA authorizes technical and peer review, advises the Secretary on research matters, ensures activities are objective and free of bias. It also establishes the NBES to advise the Director on IES policies and research priorities. The Board advises on research priorities, procedures for review, funding decisions, and Commissioner appointments for IES research centers. ESRA outlines Board requirements and IES structure with four research centers. The Board advises on research priorities, review procedures, funding decisions, and Commissioner appointments for IES research centers, including the composition, qualification, compensation, and travel expenses of the Board members. ESRA establishes IES with four research centers, each headed by a Commissioner appointed by the Director for a term of up to six years. The Center for Special Education Research (NCSER) is one of four research centers under IES, each headed by a Commissioner appointed for up to six years. NCER sponsors research to improve education quality and access for all children. NCER, part of ESRA, sponsors research to ensure high-quality education, improve student achievement, close achievement gaps, and enhance access to postsecondary education. Its duties include supporting research synthesis, promoting scientific inquiry practices, and validating research findings. NCER, part of ESRA, sponsors research to ensure high-quality education, improve student achievement, close achievement gaps, and enhance access to postsecondary education. Its duties include maintaining peer-review processes, proposing research plans, implementing valid research, ensuring relevance to education practice and policy, and disseminating research findings. The Commissioner of NCER is responsible for implementing valid research relevant to education policy and practice. They are authorized to support national research centers focusing on various topics such as adult literacy, teacher quality, and reading. The Commissioner of NCER oversees research on education policy and practice, supporting national research centers in areas like early childhood development, improving schools, teacher quality, and literacy. NCES is authorized to collect and analyze education information and statistics to meet high methodological standards. The National Center for Education Research (NCER) oversees long-term research programs funded annually and ensures high methodological standards for collecting and analyzing education information. The National Center for Education Statistics (NCES) collects and disseminates education statistics from preschool to adulthood, reporting in a timely, objective, and relevant manner free from political bias. The National Center for Education Statistics (NCES) ensures timely, objective, and relevant reports on education information and statistics, free from political bias. Other duties include publishing reports on statistics, setting standards for state educational agencies, and comparing student achievement internationally. The National Center for Education Statistics (NCES) is responsible for collecting statistics, setting standards for state educational agencies, and comparing student achievement internationally. The Commissioner of NCES can award grants, contracts, or cooperative agreements to carry out these duties, including collecting data on education reform activities, early childhood school readiness, student achievement in reading, math, and science, secondary school completions, dropouts, and adult literacy skills. The National Center for Education Statistics (NCES) collects data on various topics including state and local education reform activities, early childhood school readiness, student achievement in reading, math, and science, secondary school completions, dropouts, adult literacy skills, teaching practices, violence affecting students and school personnel, education financing and management, social and economic status of children, and educational technology use in elementary and secondary education. The National Center for Education Statistics collects data on various topics including violence affecting students and school personnel, education financing and management, social and economic status of children, educational technology use in schools, access to early childhood programs, before and after-school programs, vocational and technical education participation, and school library availability. Data must be disaggregated by various demographics. The National Center for Education Statistics collects data on various topics including violence affecting students and school personnel, education financing and management, social and economic status of children, educational technology use in schools, access to early childhood programs, before and after-school programs, vocational and technical education participation, and school library availability. Data must be disaggregated by various demographics such as gender, race, ethnicity, socioeconomic status, limited English proficiency, mobility, disability, and urban, rural, and suburban districts to facilitate educational and policy decision making. ESRA Part D authorizes NCEE to support evaluation, technical assistance, development, and dissemination activities. The National Center for Education Statistics (NCEE) supports evaluation, technical assistance, development, and dissemination activities. The mission of NCEE is to provide technical assistance, conduct evaluations of federal education programs, determine their impact on student academic achievement, support synthesis and dissemination of results, and encourage the use of valid education research and evaluation throughout the United States. The Commissioner of NCEE is authorized to carry out these activities. The National Center for Education Statistics (NCEE) is authorized to conduct evaluations of federal education programs, establish evaluation methodology, adhere to high standards of quality, and evaluate programs under ESRA requirements. The NCEE is required to evaluate programs under Title I of ESEA and review other federal education program evaluations. Technical assistance is provided through the REL program. The Director of IES contracts with 10 RELs to serve children across the US. The NCEE evaluates programs under Title I of ESEA and other federal education programs. The Director of IES contracts with 10 RELs to provide technical assistance to meet the needs of children across the US. RELs conduct applied research, development, dissemination, and training for SEAs, LEAs, and school boards. The Regional Educational Laboratories (RELs) conduct research, provide training, and offer technical assistance to SEAs, LEAs, school boards, and state boards of education on implementing the ESEA. They also focus on research in teaching methods, assessment tools, and curriculum frameworks, as well as replicating and adapting successful educational practices. Additionally, RELs facilitate communication between educational experts, school officials, teachers, and parents. The duties of the RELs include facilitating communication between educational experts, school officials, teachers, parents, and librarians to assist schools in meeting state education goals, surveying regional needs, developing a plan to address those needs, conducting applied research, and engaging in dissemination activities. The Commissioner of NCEE must ensure independent evaluations of each REL and report the results to relevant committees. The Commissioner of NCEE must provide independent evaluations of each of the RELs and report the results to relevant committees of Congress, the NSEB, and the appropriate REL. Part E of ESRA authorizes NCSER to sponsor research to expand knowledge and understanding of the needs of infants, toddlers, and children with disabilities to improve educational outcomes and support the implementation of IDEA. The National Center for Special Education Research (NCSER) aims to improve developmental, educational, and transitional outcomes for individuals with disabilities, sponsor research to enhance services under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA), and evaluate IDEA implementation. NCSER's duties include identifying effective practices and interventions to support learning, improve academic achievement, and promote participation in general education settings. The National Center for Special Education Research (NCSER) focuses on improving outcomes for individuals with disabilities under IDEA by identifying effective practices, services, and interventions to support learning, academic achievement, and participation in general education settings. NCSER also addresses issues such as overidentification and underidentification of children with disabilities, personnel preparation, excess costs of educating students with disabilities, and the special needs of limited English proficient children with disabilities. The National Center for Special Education Research (NCSER) focuses on improving outcomes for individuals with disabilities under IDEA by identifying effective practices, services, and interventions. The Commissioner of NCSER is authorized to award grants for research activities in accordance with established standards. NCSER also synthesizes and disseminates research findings in special education. The National Center for Special Education Research (NCSER) follows NCER standards for research and development activities. Title II of P.L. 107-279, known as the Educational Technical Assistance Act (ETAA), authorizes grants for technical assistance and evaluation purposes. $400 million in appropriations were authorized for ESRA activities in FY2003, with additional funding for subsequent years. Funding for Regional Educational Laboratories (RELs) was also authorized. Although these authorities expired in FY2008, funding has continued through annual appropriations legislation. Title II of P.L. 107-279, the Educational Technical Assistance Act (ETAA), authorizes grants for technical assistance and evaluation purposes. The Secretary can award grants to local entities and states for data systems. Not less than 20 grants are awarded for comprehensive centers across 10 regions, working with SEAs, LEAs, and schools. ETAA outlines authorized activities for the comprehensive centers. The Educational Technical Assistance Act (ETAA) authorizes grants for technical assistance to local entities across 10 regions. Each comprehensive center must work with SEAs, LEAs, and schools in its region, providing training, disseminating information, and developing teacher training models. The Educational Technical Assistance Act (ETAA) authorizes grants for technical assistance to local entities across 10 regions. Each comprehensive center coordinates activities with its local REL, NCEE, the Office of the Secretary, state service agency, and other technical assistance providers. They also establish an advisory board and report annually to the Secretary. The Secretary conducts independent evaluations of the comprehensive centers and reports to congressional committees and the Director of IES. The Educational Technical Assistance Act (ETAA) authorizes the Secretary to conduct evaluations of comprehensive centers and report to congressional committees. The Secretary can also make grants to SEAs for statewide data systems to manage student data efficiently. Applications must meet technical quality standards and address ESEA requirements. The Secretary can award grants for data systems that meet ESEA requirements. Funding for Title II activities was authorized until FY2008, with continued funding through annual appropriations. Title III of P.L. 107-279 established the National Assessment Governing Board. The National Assessment of Educational Progress Authorization Act (NAEPAA) established the National Assessment Governing Board (NAGB) and the Commissioner of Education Statistics conducts the National Assessment of Educational Progress (NAEP), which includes national and state assessment programs in reading and mathematics. Funding for these activities has continued through annual appropriations since FY2008. The NAEP is a series of assessments including national, state, long-term trend, and urban district assessments in reading and mathematics. Participation in the assessments is voluntary for students and schools. The NAEP assessment program allows states to voluntarily participate in administering assessments to a sample size for state-level results. The Assessment Board, consisting of various stakeholders, formulates policy guidelines for NAEP. The Assessment Board for the NAEP includes governors, state legislators, educators, and testing experts. Their duties include selecting subjects to assess, setting achievement levels, and ensuring validity and reliability of assessments. The Assessment Board for the NAEP is responsible for developing appropriate student achievement levels, assessment objectives, and test specifications based on professional standards. They also involve teachers, administrators, parents, and the public in the assessment review process to ensure validity and reliability. The methodology of the assessment is designed with input from technical experts to ensure validity and reliability. The Assessment Board for the NAEP develops student achievement levels, assessment objectives, and test specifications with input from technical experts. They measure academic achievement in grades 4, 8, and 12, develop reporting guidelines, standards for comparisons, and plan the public release of reports. $4.6 million was appropriated for FY2003. The National Assessment Governing Board oversees the development of student achievement levels and assessment objectives for the NAEP. Funding of $4.6 million was authorized for FY2003, with continued funding through annual appropriations legislation. During the 113th and 114th Congress, bills were passed to reauthorize ESRA, ETAA, and NAEPAA, amending provisions related to IES independence, research standards, technical assistance, evaluation, privacy protection, student assessment oversight, and IES accountability. Both H.R. 4366 and S. 227 proposed reauthorization of ESRA, ETAA, and NAEPAA, with amendments related to IES independence, research standards, technical assistance, evaluation, privacy protection, student assessment oversight, and IES accountability. The bills also aimed to have at least two board members on NBES who are practitioners knowledgeable about US education needs.
